fr:mainmatter.fr:p: This post discuss the universe in type theory, based on Egbert Rijke's Introduction to Homotopy Type Theory and NLab. In this post, we regard universe as the representation of types in an internal model of the type theory (Tarski universe or universe Ã la Tarski).

A universe consist of a type \mathcal {U} with a type family \mathcal {T} over \mathcal {U}. Forall X:\mathcal {U} we think of X as an encoding (representation) of the actual type \mathcal {T}(X). The type family \mathcal {T} is therefore called a unversal type family.

There several reasons to equip type theory with universes. It enables us to define new type families over inductive types, using induction principle. For instance, we can define relations over \mathbb {N}, such as ordering relations \leq . We will soon meet the idea of observational equality for a particular type, different from identity types. Another reason is that it allows us to define types equipped with structure such as group.

A universe consists of a type \mathcal {U} of which the elements are representations of types. It is equipped with a type family \mathcal {T} indexed by \mathcal {U} called universal type family. The universe is closed under all the type constructors in the sense that it comes equipped with the following structure:
\mathcal {U} is closed under \Pi , equipped with a function \check {\Pi }:\Pi _{(X:\mathcal {U})}(\mathcal {T}(X)\to \mathcal {U})\to \mathcal {U} for which the judgemental equality \mathcal {T}(\check {\Pi }(X,P))\equiv \Pi _{(x:\mathcal {T}(X))}\mathcal {T}(P(x)) holds forall X:\mathcal {U} and P:\mathcal {T}(X)\to \mathcal {U}.
\mathcal {U} is closed under \Sigma , equipped with a function \check {\Sigma }:\Pi _{(X:\mathcal {U})}(\mathcal {T}(X)\to \mathcal {U})\to \mathcal {U} for which the judgemental equality \mathcal {T}(\check {\Sigma }(X,P))\equiv \Sigma _{(x:\mathcal {T}(X))}\mathcal {T}(P(x)) holds forall X:\mathcal {U} and P:\mathcal {T}(X)\to \mathcal {U}.
\mathcal {U} is closed under identity types, equipped with a function \check {I}:\Pi _{(X:\mathcal {U})}\mathcal {T}(X)\to \mathcal {T}(X)\to \mathcal {U} for which the judgemental equality \mathcal {T}(\check {I}(X,x,y))\equiv (x=y) holds forall X:\mathcal {U} and x,y:\mathcal {T}(X).
\mathcal {U} is closed under coproducts, equipped with a function \check {+}:\Pi _{(X:\mathcal {U})}(\mathcal {T}(X)\to \mathcal {U})\to \mathcal {U} that satisfies the judgemental equality \mathcal {T}(X\check {+}P)\equiv \mathcal {T}(X)+\mathcal {T}(P)
\mathcal {U} contains elements \check {\textbf {1}}, \check {\textbf {0}}, \check {\mathbb {N}} : \mathcal {U} that satisfies the judgemental equality \mathcal {T}(\check {\textbf {0}})\equiv \textbf {0}, \\ \mathcal {T}(\check {\textbf {1}})\equiv \textbf {1}, \\ \mathcal {T}(\check {\mathbb {N}})\equiv \mathbb {N} Consider a universe \mathcal {U} and a type A in context \Gamma . We say that A is a type in \mathcal {U} or that \mathcal {U} contains A, if there is an element \check {A}:\mathcal {U} such that \Gamma \vdash \mathcal {T}(\check {A})\equiv A\space \space \text {type} holds.

Sometimes we may consider the universe \mathcal {U} itself to be a type in some universes. If we have only one \mathcal {U}, the Russell Paradox may arise. Therefore we assume that there are enough universes
Using the assumption we can obtain many specific universes.
The base universee \mathcal {U}_0 is defined using universe postulate with empty context.
Using successor universes we can create an infinite tower of universes.

Now we give the example of observational equality of \mathbb {N}. The key idea is to define a recursive function that reduce the arguments. Observational equality an inductively defined relation, which gives us an algorithm for checking equality on \mathbb {N}. It can be used to show that equality of natural numbers is decidable.

The observational equality of \mathbb {N} is a binary relation \text {Eq}_\mathbb {N}:\mathbb {N}\to (\mathbb {N}\to \mathcal {U}_0) satisfies \begin {align*} \text {Eq}_\mathbb {N}(0)(0) &\equiv \textbf {1} \\ \text {Eq}_\mathbb {N}(0)(\text {succ}(n)) &\equiv \textbf {0} \\ \text {Eq}_\mathbb {N}(\text {succ}(m))(0) &\equiv \textbf {0} \\ \text {Eq}_\mathbb {N}(\text {succ}(m))(\text {succ}(n)) &\equiv \text {Eq}_\mathbb {N}(m)(n) \end {align*}
730#313unstable-313.xmlProofdef-004H We define \text {Eq} by double induction on \mathbb {N}. By the first application of induction it suffices to provide \begin {align*} &E_0:\mathbb {N}\to \mathcal {U}_0 \\ &E_S:\mathbb {N}\to ((\mathbb {N}\to \mathcal {U}_0)\to (\mathbb {N}\to \mathcal {U}_0)) \end {align*} we define E_0 by induction: \begin {align*} &E_0(0) \equiv \textbf {1}\\ &E_0(\text {succ}(n)) \equiv \textbf {0} \end {align*} and also define E_S by induction: \begin {align*} &E_S(n,X,0)\equiv \textbf {0}\\ &E_S(n,X,\text {succ}(m))\equiv X(m) \end {align*} Therefore we have by the computation rule for the first induction that the following judgemental equality holds. \begin {align*} \text {Eq}(0,m) &\equiv E_0(m) \\ \text {Eq}(\text {succ}(n),m) &\equiv E_S(n,\text {Eq}(n),m) \end {align*}

Observational equality of \mathbb {N} is a reflexive relation, i.e. we have \text {refl-Eq}_\mathbb {N}:\Pi _{(n:\mathbb {N})}\text {Eq}_\mathbb {N}(n,n) which is witnessed by induction on n. \begin {align*} \text {refl-Eq}_\mathbb {N}(0) &\equiv \star \\ \text {refl-Eq}_\mathbb {N}(\text {succ}(n)) &\equiv \text {refl-Eq}_\mathbb {N}(n) \end {align*}
This leads to an interesting dual perspective on equality. For any two natural numbers m and n we have (m=n)\leftrightarrow \text {Eq}_\mathbb {N}(m,n)

Using the observational equality of \mathbb {N} we can prove Peano's seventh and eighth axioms.
For any two natural numbers m and n we have (m = n)\leftrightarrow (\text {succ}(m) = \text {succ}(n))
For any natural number n we have 0 \not = \text {succ}(n)
